Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Carbon allocation strategies in understory native and invasive woody plants
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the largest management concerns in natural forests of the Eastern U.S. is the invasion of ornamental shrubs from Europe and Asia. These plants outcompete native species for resources, reducing plant species diversity and altering the cycling of forest nutrients. This project will explore differences in energy use between native and invasive shrub species to advance our understanding of when and why exotic plants will exclude native plants. Research findings will help forest managers make decisions that will best protect U.S. forests in the face of environmental change. The project will support the research and training of a doctoral student, expanding the student's experimental and analytical skills. Undergraduate students from underrepresented groups will participate in hands-on research; through this engagement, the research will foster a new generation of critically thinking young scientists.

This project characterizes carbon allocation patterns in native and invasive woody plants growing in deciduous forest understories. It will evaluate the relationship between growth rates and carbon storage allocation, and how allocation to defense mediates this relationship. Researchers will test the general hypothesis that invasive plants allocate more carbon toward growth at the expense of storage allocation in order to outcompete native plants for resources. Storage compounds, in the form of starches and simple sugars, are critical for recovery from tissue damage and protection from frost events. Preliminary data show that invasive species have higher growth rates and produce more leaves in response to leaf removal, but it is unknown whether this comes at a loss of storage compounds that promote survival. An insect feeding experiment on a range of native and invasive species' leaves will be carried out to assess allocation to physical and chemical defenses, and a freezing experiment will elucidate the relationship between stem starch and sugar concentrations in different species and their ability to tolerate cold temperatures. These activities will test the hypothesis that invasive species possess lower carbon storage and defense allocation than native species, and that this difference leads to lower survival in response to leaf removal and freezing events, and lower resistance to herbivore feeding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many non-native deciduous shrub and tree species from Europe and Asia are invasive in shaded forest understories of Eastern North America where low light is hypothesized to lead to carbon limitation. The mechanisms of invasive spread remain unknown yet are critical to invasive species control and our understanding of species success in novel environments. Invasive woody species (hereafter 'invaders') are often more productive than their native counterparts, and many invaders hold their leaves for longer in the fall than native species. This extended leaf phenology contributes to invaders' greater annual carbon gain. We explored carbon allocation strategies in closely related native and invasive species to understand whether greater productivity and carbon gain documented in invaders comes at the expense of two important survival pools: storage and defense. In the forest understory, carbon storage (in the form of non-structural carbohydrates) is critical for leaf production in the spring and survival following tissue damage from extreme events or herbivory. Additionally, many species resist herbivory by producing physical and chemical defenses. Invaders may not need to invest as heavily in defense and storage if they evade herbivory, but it is unclear whether they experience higher mortality during extreme events like freezing. We hypothesized that greater growth in invaders leads to lower relative allocation to storage and defenses, while native species show greater relative allocation to storage and defense. We also expected that native species would exhibit greater resistance to herbivory and higher survival following intense defoliation.  

We measured storage and defense investment in phylogenetically paired native and invasive woody species co-occurring in a common garden at Syracuse University. We then conducted a generalist herbivore feeding experiment to understand native and invasive plant palatability and the extent to which defense-related leaf traits deter two caterpillar species common in deciduous forests. We also explored whether tradeoffs exist between relative allocation to productivity, defense, and storage. Finally, we performed a three year defoliation experiment on saplings of four co-occurring native and invasive species in the forest understory to evaluate species responses to varying levels of leaf removal. 

We found that native species allocate more carbohydrate to storage throughout the year than invasive species, indicating that natives are potentially better equipped to produce new tissues following damage or protect existing tissues from freezing via carbon-based anti-freeze compounds. However, we found that invaders tend to invest more in physical defense in their leaves than native species. Despite these differences in energy allocation between natives and invaders, we did not find evidence of tradeoffs between productivity, defense, and storage in this group of species. This result likely indicates that there are other facets of the carbon budget that influence tradeoffs in woody species, such as reproductive allocation or nutrient exchange with mycorrhizal fungi. Furthermore, we did not observe differences in growth rate between caterpillars feeding on invasive species and those provided with leaves from native species. Thus, invasive woody species do not appear to escape insect herbivory in the forest understory, despite possessing higher defense-related leaf traits. Finally, after three years of defoliation treatments in 160 saplings, we did not find differences in defoliation responses between native and invasive species. However, both groups experienced significant growth reductions and higher mortality with increasing defoliation intensity.

Overall, our results suggest that closely related native and invasive species differ in their carbon allocation strategies, but these differences did not translate to differences in herbivory or defoliation risk in our experiments. However, this study paves the way for future studies to evaluate the most prominent sources of mortality in native and invasive understory species, and the extent to which other energy pools, like fruit and flower production (as well as frequency), differ between natives and invaders and translate to differences in fitness.

This study has resulted in one publication, with two forthcoming. It supported the work and research experience of two field/lab technicians, one of which is now a Master's student at Syracuse University. The PhD student supported by this grant presented results at three Ecological Society of America conferences and participated in weekly scientific outreach at a local after-school community center during her tenure at Syracuse University.
